2.1 What is JavaScript

  • Lightweight, crossplatform, object-oriented computer programming language
  • Part of the three core web dev technologies
  • Today, JS can be used in different places.
    • Client side: Used in browser
    • Server side: Uses Node.js to work on servers as well
  • Essential for modern websites
  • Frameworks / libraries like React, Angular are 100% based on JavaScript: You need to master JavaScript to use them!

2.2 The role of JavaScript in web development

JavaScript is an essential part of modern web design and development, along with HTML and CSS.

2.3 Datatypes in JavaScript

  • Number:

    Floating point numbers, for decimals and integers

    All number values in JS are floats, even if they appear as ints

  • String:

    Sequence of characters, used for text

  • Boolean:

    Logical data type that can only be true or false

  • Undefined:

    Data type of a variable that does not have a value yet

  • Null:

    Also means 'non-existant', but slightly more specific than undefined.

Dynamic typing***

In JavaScript, data types are automatically assigned to variables.

It will automatically figure out what the right datatype is, and change them accordingly.

2.4 Naming variables

Keep names of variables simple, yet descriptive. It's easier to work with variables and names with meaning.

Using camel case notation is the most common JavaScript naming convention.

Naming rules*

  • Variables cannot start with numbers or symbols, except: $ or _.
  • JS keywords cannot be used for variable names.

Examples of JavaScript variables

// console.log('Hello there again!');

//variables of different data types
var firstName = 'John';
var lastName = 'Smith';
var age = 28;
var fullAge = true;

//Undefined value
var job;

//Value declaration
job = 'teacher';

console.log(firstName, lastName, age, fullAge, job);

// Variable naming rules
var _3Years = 3;
var johnMark = 'John and Mark';
//var if = 23;      <-- cannot be used

2.5 Variable Mutation and Type Coersion

JavaScript automatically converts variable types as its needed, allowing different value types to be combined.

Values can be iterated and changed. JavaScript will automatically adjust the new value to the corresponding datatype.

alert()**

Shows messages in a popup window in the browser.

Stops JS until the alert is addressed.

prompt()**

Asks the users for an input which can be used in for example:

var lastName = prompt('What is his last name?');

Examples of variable mutation and type coersion

/**************************
 Variable mutations and type coersion
 */

 var firstName = 'John';
 var age = 28;

 console.log(firstName + ' ' + age); //Type coersion

 var job, isMarried; //Multiple value declarations
 job = 'teacher';
 isMarried = false;

 console.log(firstName + ' is a ' + age + ' year old ' + job + '. Is he married? ' + isMarried);

 // Variable mutation
 age = 'twenty eight';
 job = 'driver';

 console.log(firstName + ' is a ' + age + ' year old ' + job + '. Is he married? ' + isMarried);

 var lastName = prompt('What is his last name?');
 console.log(firstName + '\'s last name is ' + lastName);

2.6 Basic operators

  • Math operators
    • + - * / %
  • Logical operators
    • True / False
  • Typeof operators
    • Returns the type of value

Examples of basic operators

// Math operators
//   var yearJohn = yearNow - age;
console.log('John is born in ' + (yearNow - age));
console.log(yearNow + 2);

//   Logical operators
var ageJohn = yearJohn;
var ageMark = yearMark;
var johnOlder = ageJohn < ageMark;
console.log(johnOlder);

//Typeof operator - Returns the value type.
console.log(typeof johnOlder); //bool
console.log(typeof ageJohn); //number
var x;
console.log(typeof x); //Undefined

Operator precedence

The standard order of operations in JavaScript. Decides which operators get priority. See the below link for the full table.

Operator procedence table

Equal sign

The equal sign is also an operator, but with a very low procedence value to make sure it is almost always the last operator to be processed.

Multiple assignments

JavaScript can process different value assignments at once, as well as return different values in the same line. 

var x, y;
 x = y = (3 + 5) * 4 - 6; // 8 * 4 - 6 // 32 - 6 // = 26
// Also multiple value assignments at once.

 console.log(x, y);

Other operators

X = x * 2; is the same as x *= 2;

The same goes for:

+=

-=

etc...

x++;**

This is the same as x + 1; or x += 1

Coding & other Challenge 1

Mark and John are trying to compare their BMI, which is calculated using the formula: BMI = mass / height2= mass / (height * height -height in meters and mass in kg.

Instructions for challenge 1

  • Store each of Mark and John's mass and height values.
  • Calculate their BMIs
  • Create a boolean variable containing information about who has highest BMI.
  • Print a string with the results.

Solution for challenge 1

/*********************
 * CODING CHALLENGE 1
 */
console.log('Coding Challenge 1 - BMI');

//Variables
heightJohn = prompt('What is John\'s height in meters?');
massJohn = prompt('What is John\'s weight in kilos?');
heightMark = prompt('What is Mark\'s height in meters?');
massMark = prompt('What is Mark\'s weight in kilos?');

//BMI calculator
var isbmiJohn = massJohn / heightJohn ^ 2;
var isbmiMark = massMark / heightMark ^ 2;

console.log('John: ' + isbmiJohn + 'BMI');
console.log('Mark: ' + isbmiMark + 'BMI');

var markIsHigher = isbmiMark > isbmiJohn;
var johnIsHigher = isbmiMark < isbmiJohn;

//Result
if (markIsHigher) {
  console.log('Mark has a higher BMI than John');
} else if (johnIsHigher) {
  console.log('John has a higher BMI than Mark');
} else if (markIsHigher == undefined || johnIsHigher == undefined) {
  console.log('Couldn\'t calculate BMI.');
}

2.7 If / else statements

Conditional decision maker in JavaScript, very much like most other coding languages.

The conventional structure of an if / else statement in JavaScript looks like:

var firstName = 'John';
var civilStatus = 'single';

//Returns only IF...
if (civilStatus == 'married') {
  console.log(firstName + ' is married.');
} else { //else returns
  console.log(firstName + ' will hopefully marry soon.);
}

A condition is automatically checked for truth:

var isMarried = true;

if (isMarried /*== is true*/) {
  ...
}

Having to clarify "== true" is not necessary.

2.8 Boolean logic

![Boolean Truthtable](image/.. images/Slide3.png)

2.9 Ternary operator and Switch statements

There is a shorthand version of if / else statements in JavaScript, called the ternary operator.

It is ordered like:

  • variable (age)
  • conditional operator (>=)
  • if true (?)
  • result (console.log('true'))
  • else (:)
  • alternative result (console.log('false'))

Example

/*****************
 * The ternary operator
 */
console.log('The Ternary Operator and Switch Statements:');

var firstName = 'Sara';
var age = 15;

age >= 18 ? console.log(firstName + ' drinks beer.')
: console.log(firstName + ' drinks soda.')

The console will return the statement that Sara drinks soda.

Assigning values to variables in the ternary operator 

var drink = age >= 18 ? 'beer' : 'juice';

Elements:

  • variable drink
  • Is age greater or equal to 18?
  • If so, then 'beer'
  • Else : 'juice'

2.10 Switch Statement

var job = 'teacher';
switch (job) {
  case 'teacher':
    console.log(firstName + ' teaches kids how to code');
    break;
  case 'driver':
    console.log(firstName + ' drives an uber in Lisbon');
    break;
  case 'designer':
    console.log(firstName + ' designs websites');
    break;
  default:
    console.log(firstName + ' does something else.');
}

What it does

It switches the variable job between the three different cases. It returns one of the 3 cases if they apply to variable job. Otherwise, they will return ' does something else.'.

Break

To ensure the statement will stop evaluating at the right case, the break keyword needs to be stated after every block.

break;

Default

default:
    console.log(firstName + ' does something else.');

The statement that runs if none of the others apply.

Multiple case assignments

A statement can be run when multiple cases meet the criteria, as shown below:

switch (job) {
  case 'teacher':
  case 'instructor':
    console.log(firstName + ' teaches kids how to code');
    break;

Both 'teacher' and 'instructor' will return the value.

2.11 Truthy and Falsy Values and Equality Operators

Falsy values are

  • undefined
  • null
  • 0
  • ''
  • NaN

These values will return as false when evaluated in an if/else statement.

Values that are not falsey are truthy values.

Examples of truthy values

var height;

if (height) {
  console.log('Variable is defined');
} else {
  console.log('Variable has not been defined');
}

The above example shows a method to determine wether a variable is defined or not.

0 (zero)

When evaluating variables such as number, we need to make sure that 0 (zero) is considered as a number input.

var height = 0;

if (height || height === 0) {
  console.log('Variable is defined');
} else {
  console.log('Variable has not been defined');
}

2.12 Equal symbol

There is different uses for the equal symbol in JavaScript, the main ones being:

  • assignment of values (var x = 10),
  • type coersing equality operators (x == 9),
  • strict equality operators (x === 10).

The difference between coersing equality operators and strict equality operators is that the strict operator does not coers variable types, while the coersing equality operator does.

Using the strict equality operator (===) is important in assuring values are taken as they are.

Coding & other Challenge 2 - Basketball Scores

John and mike both play basketball in different teams. In the latest 3 games, John's team scored 89, 120 and 103 points, while Mike's team scored 116, 94 and 123 points.

Instructions for challenge 2

  1. Calculate the average score for each team.
  2. Decide which team wins in average (highest average score), and print the winner to the console. Also include the average score in the output.
  3. Then change the scores to show different winners. Don't forget to take into account there might be a draw (same average score).
  4. Extra: Mary also plays basketball, and her team scored 97, 134 and 105 points. Like before, log the average winner to the console.
  5. Like before, change the scores to generate different winners, keeping in mind there might be draws.

Solution for challenge 2

/******************
 * Coding challenge 2 - Basketball Score
 */
console.log('Coding challenge 2 - Basketball Score');

var johnGame1 = 89;
var johnGame2 = 120;
var johnGame3 = 103;

var mikeGame1 = 116;
var mikeGame2 = 94;
var mikeGame3 = 123;

var maryGame1 = 97;
var maryGame2 = 134;
var maryGame3 = 105;

var johnAvg = (johnGame1 + johnGame2 + johnGame3) / 3;
var mikeAvg = (mikeGame1 + mikeGame2 + mikeGame3) / 3;
var maryAvg = (maryGame1 + maryGame2 + maryGame3) / 3;

if (johnAvg > mikeAvg && johnAvg > maryAvg) {
  console.log('John\'s team has the highest average score!');
  console.log('Their team\'s average score: ' + johnAvg);
  if (mikeAvg > maryAvg) {
    console.log('Mike\'s team beat Mary\'s team with ' + (mikeAvg - maryAvg) + ' points.');
  } else if (mikeAvg < maryAvg) {
    console.log('Mary\'s team beat Mike\'s team with ' + (maryAvg - mikeAvg) + ' points.');
  } else {
    console.log('Mary and Mike have a draw!');
  }
} else if (mikeAvg > johnAvg && mikeAvg > maryAvg) {
  console.log('Mike\'s team has the highest average score!');
  console.log('Their team\'s average score: ' + mikeAvg);
  if (johnAvg > maryAvg) {
    console.loJ('john\'s team beat Mary\'s team with ' + (johnAvg - maryAvg) + ' points.');
  } else if (johnAvg < maryAvg) {
    console.log('Mary\'s team beat John\'s team with ' + (maryAvg - johnAvg) + ' points.');
  } else {
    console.log('Mary and john have a draw!');
  }
} else if (maryAvg > johnAvg && maryAvg > mikeAvg) {
  console.log('Mary\'s team has the highest average score!');
  console.log('Their team\'s average score: ' + maryAvg);
  if (johnAvg > mikeAvg) {
    console.log('john\'s team beat Mike\'s team with ' + (johnAvg - mikeAvg) + ' points.');
  } else if (johnAvg < mikeAvg) {
    console.log('Mike\'s team beat John\'s team with ' + (mikeAvg - johnAvg) + ' points.');
  } else {
    console.log('Mike and john have a draw!');
  }
} else {
  console.log('All teams scored a draw!');
  console.log('Average score: ' + johnAvg);
}

2.13 Functions

Functions are containers that can hold lines of code, which we can pass arguments.

function calculateAge(birthYear) {
  return 2020 - birthYear;
}

ageJohn = calculateAge(1990);
ageMike = calculateAge(1963);
ageSara = calculateAge(1987);

console.log(ageJohn, ageMike, ageSara);

Functions can pass multiple arguments, and return multiple items. They help with avoiding repeat code.

Functions with multiple arguments

function yearsUntilRetirement(year, firstName)
{
  var age = calculateAge(year)
  var retirement = 65 - age;
  if (retirement > 0) {
    console.log(firstName + ' retires in ' + retirement + ' years.')
  } else {
    console.log(firstName + ' is retired')
  }
}

yearsUntilRetirement(1990, 'John');
yearsUntilRetirement(1934, 'Mike');
yearsUntilRetirement(1992, 'Sara');

2.14 Function statements and expressions

There is a different way of writing functions in JavaScript, instead of using function statements/declaration: the function expression.

A function declaration

The previous way:

function whatDoYouDo(job, firstName){
  /*function log*/
}

A function expression

var whatDoYouDo = function(job, firstName); {
  /*function log*/
}

Variable whatDoYouDo is assigned the function and will use the function log, with the proper arguments, whenever called upon.

Function expression extended code

var whatDoYouDo = function(job, firstName) {
  switch(job) {
    case 'teacher':
      return firstName + ' teaches kids';
    case 'driver':
      return firstName + ' drives cars';
    case 'designer':
      return firstName + ' makes websites';
    default:
      return firstName + ' does something else.';
  }
}

console.log(whatDoYouDo('teacher', 'John'));
console.log(whatDoYouDo('driver', 'Sara'));
console.log(whatDoYouDo('retired', 'Mike'));

JavaScript expressions are pieces of code that always produce a value, and it doesn't matter how long they are, as long as the code results in a single value, it is an expression.

2.15 Arrays

Arrays are collections of variables, which can be of the same or different datatypes.

Different ways of writing arrays

//1 (most common)
var names = ['John', 'Mark', 'Sara'];

//2
var years = new Array(1990, 1964, 1958);

Arrays are 0 (zero) based, starting counting items at zero.

Array items can be called back by:

console.log(names[2]);

Data in the array can also be mutated or amended.

names[1] = 'Ben'; & names[names.length] = 'Mary';

Different datatypes

var john = ['John', 'Smith', 1990, 'teacher', false];

Arrays can consist of different datatypes. There are certain functions that can be applied to arrays called methods:

john.push('blue');

This pushes 'blue' as an item at the back on john's array.

Other methods

//Add elements to the end:
john.push('Dogs');
//Add elements to the start:
john.unshift('Mr.');

//Removes elements at the end:
john.pop();

//Removes elements at the beginning:
john.shift();

//Returns the position at which position the element appears in the array.
john.indexOf(1990)
The index method

Using the index method is not also useful to finding the position of elements within arrays, but also for checking of certain elements are present within an array.

console.log(john, indexOf(birthMonth)); will return a value of -1 meaning birthMonth is not defined in the array john.

var isDesigner = john.indexOf('designer') === -1 ? 'John is not a graphic designer' : 'John is a graphic designer';

console.log(isDesigner);

Coding & other challenge 3 - Tip calculator

Instructions for challenge 3

John and his family ent on a holiday and went to 3 different restaurants. The bills were $123, $48 and $268.

To tip the waiter a fair amount, John created a simple tip calculator (as a function). He likes to tip 20% of the bill when the bull is less than $50, 15% when the bill is between $50 and $200, and 10% if the bill is more than $200.

In the end, John would like to have 2 arrays:

  1. Containing all three tips (one for each bill).
  2. Containing all three final paid amounts (bill + tip).

Solution for challenge 3

/*************
 * Coding challenge 3 - Tip calculator
 */
console.log('Tip calculator challenge:');

var restaurant = ['First restaurant', 'Second restaurant', 'Third restaurant'];
var paidNoTip = [123, 48, 268];
var paidTip = new Array;
var paidTotal = new Array;

//Tip calculator (x = number of restaurant)
function calcTip(x) {

  console.log(restaurant[x]);
  console.log('Bill without tip: $' + paidNoTip[x]);

  //New array space
  paidTip.unshift;
  paidTotal.unshift;

  if (paidNoTip[x] <= 50) {
    paidTip[x] = (paidNoTip[x] * 0.2); //Calculates tip amount
    paidTotal[x] = (paidTip[x] + paidNoTip[x]); //Adds up to total amount
    //result:
    console.log('Tip amount: $' + paidTip[x]);
    console.log('Total amount: $' + (paidTip[x] + paidNoTip[x]));
  } else if (paidNoTip[x] > 50 && paidNoTip[x] <= 200) {
    paidTip[x] = (paidNoTip[x] * 0.15); //Calculates tip amount
    paidTotal[x] = (paidTip[x] + paidNoTip[x]); //Adds up to total amount
    //result:
    console.log('Tip amount: $' + paidTip[x]);
    console.log('Total amount: $' + (paidTip[x] + paidNoTip[x]));
  } else {
    paidTip[x] = (paidNoTip[x] * 0.1); //Calculates tip amount
    paidTotal[x] = (paidTip[x] + paidNoTip[x]); //Adds up to total amount
    //result:
    console.log('Tip amount: $' + paidTip[x]);
    console.log('Total amount: $' + (paidTip[x] + paidNoTip[x]));
  }
  console.log('---');
}

//Total bill + Tip
calcTip(0);
calcTip(1);
calcTip(2);

console.log(paidTip);
console.log(paidTotal);

2.16 Objects and properties

Objects can be used to group together variables of different types, wrapped in curly brackets {}.

Retreiving object properties

var john = {
  firstName: 'John' //property,
  lastName: 'Smith',
  birthYear: 1990,
  family: ['Jane', 'Mark', 'Bob', 'Emma'],
  job: 'teacher',
  isMarried: false
};

A few way to read an object property:

console.log(john.firstName); - retrieving value by dot assignment. console.log(john['lastname'] - By entering a bracket assigment.

or by calling the object property position from a variable.

var x = 'birthYear';
console.log(john[x]);

Object mutation

Property values in objects can be easily overwritten.

john.job = 'designer' - will automatically overwrite any previous assignments.

New objects can be created without any properties. They can be added at any point later.

// New object
var jan = new Object;
jane.firstName = 'Jane';
jane.birthYear = 1989;
jane['lastName'] = 'Smith';

2.17 Object and Methods

It's possible to attach functions to objects, called methods.

Looking at the code below, lets add a function to calculate John's age.

var john = {
  firstName: 'John', //property
  lastName: 'Smith',
  birthYear: 1990,
  family: ['Jane', 'Mark', 'Bob', 'Emma'],
  job: 'teacher',
  isMarried: false,

  //function or 'method' existing within an object
  calcAge: function() {
    return currentYear - this.birhtYear;
  }
};

//Calling the function
console.log(john.calcAge(1980));

this.

To refer to a current object property from within the object, use this. in front of the needed property, as show above.

Coding & other Challenge 4 - BMI part 2

Instructions for challenge 4

Let's remember the first coding challenge where Mark and John compared their BMI's. Let's now implement the same functionality with objects and methods.

  1. For each of them, create an object with properties for their full name, mass, and height.
  2. Then, add a method to each object to calculate the BMI. Save the BMI to the object and also return it from the method.
  3. In the end, log to the console who has the highest BMI, together with the full name and the respective BMI. Don't forget they might have the same BMI.

Remember: BMI = mass (kg) / height (m)^2.

Solution for challenge 4

/********************************
 * Coding challenge 4 - BMI
 */
console.log("Coding challenge 4 - BMI Part 2")

var Amy = {
  name: 'Amy Aneston',
  height: 1.58,
  mass: 64,
  
  //This lays dormant until called upon outside of the object
  calcBMI: function () {
    this.BMI = this.mass / (this.height * this.height);
    return this.BMI;
  }
};

var Jim = {
  name: 'Jim Thornby',
  height: 1.75,
  mass: 84,

  //This lays dormant until called upon outside of the object
  calcBMI: function () {
    this.BMI = this.mass / (this.height * this.height);
    return this.BMI;
  }
}

//BETTER OPTION BELOW
// Run these
/*Amy.calcBMI();
Jim.calcBMI();

// The above functions need to run first to collect values for the conditionals to run next.
if (Amy.BMI > Jim.BMI) {
  console.log('Amy\'s BMI is higher than Jim\'s.' + ' Her BMI is: ' + Amy.BMI);
  console.log('Jim\'s BMI is ' + Jim.BMI);
} else if (Amy.BMI < Jim.BMI) {
  console.log('Jim\'s BMI is higher than Amy\'s.' + ' His BMI is: ' + Jim.BMI);
  console.log('Amy\'s BMI is ' + Amy.BMI);
} else {
  console.log('Amy and Jim have the same BMI: ' + Amy.BMI);
};
*/

if (Amy.calcBMI() > Jim.calcBMI()) {
  console.log('Amy\'s BMI is higher than Jim\'s.' + ' Her BMI is: ' + Amy.BMI);
  console.log('Jim\'s BMI is ' + Jim.BMI);
} else if (Amy.calcBMI() < Jim.calcBMI()) {
  console.log('Jim\'s BMI is higher than Amy\'s.' + ' His BMI is: ' + Jim.BMI);
  console.log('Amy\'s BMI is ' + Amy.BMI);
} else {
  Amy.calcBMI();
  Jim.calcBMI();
  console.log('Amy and Jim have the same BMI: ' + Amy.BMI);
};

2.18 Loops & Iterations

For loops

Loops are functions that repeat a certain action until a condition is met, beit a counter, measurement, value, etc.

To count from 1 to 10 in JavaScript:

for (var i = 0; i < 11; i++) {
  console.log(i);
}

For loop iterations

For loops can be used to print multiple property values from a variable:

var Amy = ['Amy', 'Aneston', 1994, 'Barista', false, 'blue'];

for (var i = 0; i < Amy.length; i++) {
  console.log(Amy[i]);
}

In the code above a for loop is used to print every array value (Amy.length) to a new line. At the same time, every loop returns the current array value with Amy[i].

Looping through arrays is one of the main uses for using for loops in JavaScript.

A benefit is that the for loop automatically prints the complete array, even when new values are added later.

While loops

The main difference between a for and a while loop is that a while loops only needs a condition.

while (i < Amy.length) {
  console.log(Amy[i]);
  i++;
}

In case of using a while loop, the i value needs to be iterated within the iteration.

Continue and break statement

Taking the for loop from before, but this time only printing strings. The typeof modifier can be used for that.

for (var i = 0; i < Amy.length; i++) {
  if (typeof Amy[i] !== 'string') continue;
  console.log(Amy[i]);
}

Continue & break in for loops

1. Continue

Continue skips and continues to the next iterations, skipping all next lines.

This can be used to filter out certain values.

2. Break

Break aborts the entire loop once ran. It can bes used to print until a certain value is met, and everything after is left out.

It can be used to retreive only a certain unique value.

Looping backwards

for (var i = Amy.length - 1; i >= 0; i--) {
  console.log(Amy[i]);
}

Setting var i to Amy.length - 1 and retracting 1 from i every loop and printing the value while i is greater than 0.

Coding & other challenge 5 - Tip calculator part 2

Instructions for challenge 5

Remember the tip calculator challenge? Let's create a more advanced version using everything we learned thus far.

This time, Amy and her family went to 5 different restaurants. The bills were $124, $48, $268, $180, and $42.

Amy likes to tip 20% when the bill is less than $50, 15% when the bill is between $50 and $200, and 10% when the bill is more than $200.

Implement a tip calculator using objects and loops:

  1. Create an object with an array for the bill values
  2. Add a method to calculate the tip
  3. This method should inclide a loop to iterate over all the paid bills and do the tip calculations
  4. as an output, create 1) a new array containing all tips, and 2) an array containing final paid amounts (bill + tip). HINT: Start with two empthy arrays [] as properties and then fill them up in the loop.

Extra after finishing

Charlie's family also went on a holiday, going to 4 different restaurants. The bills were 77, 375, 110, and 45 dollar. Charlie likes to tip 20% when the bill is less than $100, 10% between $100 and $300, and 25% if the bill is over $300.

  1. Implement the same functionality as before, this time using Charlie's tipping rules
  2. Create a function (not a method) to calculate the average of given array of tips. HINT: Loop over the array, and in each iteration store the curent sum in a variable (starting from 0). After you have the sum of the array, divide it by the number of elements in it to find the average.
  3. Calculate the average tip for each family
  4. Log to the console which family paid the highest tip on average.

Solution for challenge 5

/*******************
 * Coding challenge 5 - Tips part 2
 */
console.log('Coding challenge 5 - Tips part 2');

var amyBills = {
  billNoTip: [124, 48, 268, 180, 42], //the bills for each restaurant
  tip: [], //array of tips for each restaurant
  total: [], //array of totals paid at each restaurant
  tipAvg: 0,

  calcTip: function () { //Calculate correct tip amount
    var bill = this.billNoTip[i];

    if (bill < 50) {
      this.tip.push(bill * 0.2);
    } else if (bill >= 50) {
      this.tip.push(bill * 0.15);
    } else {
      this.tip.push(bill * 0.1);
    }
    this.total.push(this.tip[i] + bill); //Add result to tip array
  }
}

Solution for challenge 5 extra

/*****************
 * Extra
 */
console.log(' ');
console.log('Extra challenge');

var charlieBills = {
  billNoTip: [77, 375, 110, 45],
  tip: [],
  total: [],
  tipAvg: 0,

  calcTip: function () { //Calculate correct tip amount
    var bill = this.billNoTip[i];
    if (bill < 50) {
      this.tip.push(bill * 0.2);
    } else if (bill >= 50) {
      this.tip.push(bill * 0.15);
    } else {
      this.tip.push(bill * 0.1);
    }
    this.total.push(this.tip[i] + bill); //Add result to tip array
  }
}

for (var i = 0; i < charlieBills.billNoTip.length; i++) {
  charlieBills.calcTip();
  console.log('Restaurant ' + [i + 1] + '\'s bills: $' + charlieBills.billNoTip[i] + '  --- tips: $' + charlieBills.tip[i] + ' --- totals: $' + charlieBills.total[i]);
}


//Calculate tip average
calcAverage = function (x, y) {
  for (var i = 0; i < x.length; i++) {
    sum = +x[i];
  }
  y.tipAvg = sum / x.length;
}

//log average tipping for each family
calcAverage(amyBills.tip, amyBills);
calcAverage(charlieBills.tip, charlieBills);

console.log(amyBills, charlieBills);

//Who tips the most?
if (amyBills.tipAvg > charlieBills.tipAvg) {
  console.log('Amy\'s family paid more in tips on average: $' + amyBills.tipAvg + ', compared to Charlie\'s family, who paid an average of $' + charlieBills.tipAvg + '.');
} else {
  console.log('Charlie\'s family paid more in tips on average: $' + charlieBills.tipAvg + ', compared to Amy\'s family, who paid an average of $' + amyBills.tipAvg + '.');
}
